com.dautelle.realtime
Class ObjectFactory

java.lang.Object
  com.dautelle.realtime.ObjectFactory
Direct Known Subclasses:
RealtimeNumber.Factory, RealtimeObject.Factory
public abstract class ObjectFactory
extends java.lang.Object

This class represents an object factory. How and when a factory allocates its objects depends upon its real-time context. The default context (HeapContext) allocates objects on-demand (from the heap) and recycling is done through garbage collection.

Object factories can be used to accelerate the instantiation of any class. For example:

     static final ObjectFactory STRING_BUFFER_FACTORY = new ObjectFactory() {
         public Object create() {
             return new StringBuffer(26);
         }
     };
     public String toString() { 
         ObjectPool pool = STRING_BUFFER_FACTORY.currentPool();
         StringBuffer sb = (StringBuffer) pool.next(); // New or recycled.
         ... // Formats into sb.
         pool.recycle(sb);
         return sb.toString(); // Safe, sb has not been reused yet.
     }

Object factories serve also to the implementation of the Realtime interface. Here is a simple implementation:

     public class Foo implements Realtime {
         static final ObjectFactory FACTORY = new ObjectFactory() {
             public Object create() {
                 return new Foo(currentPool());
             }
         };
         private transient ObjectPool _pool; // Pool this object belongs to (if any).
         protected Foo(ObjectPool pool) { // Base constructor for sub-classes.
             _pool = pool;
         }
         public static Foo newInstance() { // Static factory method.
             return (Foo) FACTORY.currentPool().next();
         }
         public Object export() {
             if ((_pool != null) && _pool.isCurrent()) {
                 _pool.export(this);
                 _pool = _pool.getOuter();
             }
             return this;    
         }
         public Object toHeap() {
             if ((_pool != null) && !_pool.isHeap()) {
                 _pool.remove(this);
                 _pool = null;
             }
             return this;
         }
     }
Note: For easier (and faster) implementation of the Realtime interface, extending RealtimeObject is recommended.

Version:
6.0, Jan 18, 2004
Author:
Jean-Marie Dautelle

          Returns the pool for the current thread.

          Returns a pool from this factory which as been disposed and therefore always allocates on the heap.

Method Detail

create

public abstract java.lang.Object create()
Returns a new object from this factory allocated on the heap.

Returns:
a new object allocated on the heap.

newPool

protected ObjectPool newPool()
Creates a new object pool for this object factory. Sub-classes may override this method in order to use custom pools.

Returns:
a default implementation for ObjectPool.

currentPool

public final ObjectPool currentPool()
Returns the pool for the current thread. If the current thread is not executing in a PoolContext, then the heap pool is returned.

Returns:
the pool for the current thread.
See Also:
ObjectPool.isHeap()

heapPool

public final ObjectPool heapPool()
Returns a pool from this factory which as been disposed and therefore always allocates on the heap.

Returns:
a disposed pool.
